This might be the most perfect game ever made. It is everything a game should be. It has atmosphere, an engrossing storyline, amazing characters, a great soundtrack, brilliant game mechanics, intuitive game play, and cake (you actually do get cake at the end, it's pretty cool). But the real mark of this game's success is how it is 100% engrossing. When I first played it, I didn't plan on becoming an addict. I had heard about it, so I thought I should play through whatever tutorial it had, and maybe one or two levels. Turns out there isn't really a tutorial (or maybe the entire game is a tutorial) and you CANNOT stop playing it. You want to keep playing, and you do, because it is a smart game, and it reminds you that hey, you're pretty smart too.
This game is my so-far all time PC game, hands down. Too bad Valve can can olny count to 2...

Great game and a must-have for gamers. I played it a bit late maybe, considering it is 2014 as of now, but you won't be disappointed if you get it now. The length depends on your playstyle and quickness to solve puzzles. I felt it could be a tad longer, but like I said, it depends on the player. Fun dialogues and that feeling of "Really? I only had to do that to solve the puzzle? The answer was in front of my eyes all the time!" will be present throughout the game. So maybe wait for a sale or get it now, either way you will play a great game.

A classic game, truly amazing. You have to work through the Aperture Science labs using the Portal device, which lets you create (you guessed it) portals on solid surfaces that you can walk through to reach different areas. It starts off slowly with simple puzzles but soon the difficulty rises and really tests you. A great game, with great voice acting from the AI monitoring you throughout the test: GLaDOS. A truly great game (and not that long) that I feel everyone needs to at least try playing once. Give it a couple hours and you'll be hooked.

Portal is one of those kind of games that make you realize that you don't always need other players to enjoy a game.

If you like games with a good storyline, this is a game that might suit your needs. I absolutely loved how you first feel like you're following simple instructions, but start to notice many inconsistencies throughout the game. That's all I can say without spoiling too much.
I do recommend to look around a lot and try to think outside of the box ;)

The concept of the portal gun also felt like a very creative idea that gave the puzzle aspect of the game a nice twist (don't shoot me if the idea wasn't the original). Speaking of which, the puzzles can look challenging, but they're absolutely not impossible if you spend a little time thinking them through. If you hate it when you're stuck on a puzzle, then it could be frustrating, but being a puzzle solving lover I totally could find myself enjoying them the whole game through ^_^.

I'm not sure about the replay value, but the game definitely was worth the money I paid for it!

I recommend this game to people who like:
- single player
- rich storylines
- puzzles!
:D Great

After buying the Valve Complete Pack this was one of the first games that I wanted to try. Needless to say, I was not disappointed. There is a reason all of these cake memes and such exist.
 The game is well thought out and, to me, a masterpiece. Unfortunately the game is really short, a good speedrun might take around 20 minutes. I completed the game in about 3 hours blindly without looking anything up on the web. 
 Still, this is a great game and if you do not already have it, you should give it a try. It is a great game and there is no other game like it (except Portal 2 i guess...)

In the history of science, the laws of attraction is a catch phrase used when discussing the perceived nature of bodies that have a tendency to attract, thus contradicting itself as a physics law which serve to define specific properties and can be proven with experiment to be a constant. Historically, the concept of there being a known set of the laws of attraction evolved from the laws of affinity, which numbered up to ten depending upon which chemist was sourced.

In c. 391 BC, Plato built on Empedocles’ conception of philia (attractive force) and neikos (repulsive force) by postulating the first law of affinity that “likes tend toward likes”, e.g. earth to earth or water to water, etc. In 1250, Albertus Magnus applied the conception of ‘affinity’ to chemical systems and postulated four laws of affinity.
In 1687, Isaac Newton proposed that chemical affinities were due to certain forces that would likely follow similar laws analogous to the three laws of planetary motion. He expanded on these views in ‘Query 31’ of his 1704 Opticks. In 1718, after translating Newton’s Opticks, French physician and chemist Étienne Geoffroy proposed a new law of affinity that ‘whenever two substances are united that have a disposition to combine and a third is added that has a greater affinity with one of them, these two will unite, and drive out the other.’ Using this law, he published the first ever affinity tables.
In 1749, building on Geoffroy’s affinity table, French chemist J. P. Macquer published six truths of chemical affinity, which encompassed both Plato’s and Geoffroy’s affinity laws, as well as four new ones. In 1766, he published seven types of affinity in his Dictionnaire de chymie.
In this manner, most consider Isaac Newton to be the one who stimulated the discovery of the "laws of attraction". Before this, however, the ancient Greeks knew from magnetic interactions that "opposites attract" and "likes repel". This factor is modelled essentially via Coulomb's law.
In the latter half of the 19th century, the theory of electromagnetism, unified by James Clerk Maxwell in 1873, is the physics of the electromagnetic field; a field encompassing all of space which exerts a force on particles that possess the property of electric charge, and is in turn affected by the presence and motion of those particles. This effect, as modeled via Maxwell's field equations, can be thought of as the electromagnetic laws of attraction and repulsion.
With the discovery of sub-atomic particles, such as the quark (1964), and the fundamental forces, the term "laws of attraction" has been replaced with the conception of field particle exchange, and the bonding effect created therefrom. Subsequently, in the 20th century the laws of affinity were replaced by the laws of quantum chemistry and chemical thermodynamics.

Wow! I just finished Portal after just starting it today in 9  hours! Go ahead, say "that's weak", say "I can beat that". No amout of disgust will take away my fun I just had. And, by the way, I was passing a kidney stone at the same time! Now beat that! This game took just the right concentration and had enough fun for me to play while continuing to squirm, kick, and yell as a tiny piece of solidified uric acid passed it's way down my left uter from my kidney heading to my bladder. I don't know of any other game that occupied my time and mind better than this one. How's that for a vote of GREAT GAME?!? And I've passed other stones with other games. No contest! The puzzles got difficult at the right rate and I learned everything I needed to know to finish the final battle. Great song at the end too. Ok, now someone will have to play it through for the first time while giving birth in order to beat my enjoyable time with this classic game! Buy it, you'll like it!

This game is a classic, even though i never played it before now, it is referenced in so much and has so many tribute videos, art, webcomics, etc. Needless to say that my exceptations were high when i started it and in most cases expectations are never fulfilled.
Not with this game. It is simply in its own class of greatnes. It is one of those games you must have played.
The concept is simple and effective, it's a FPP (First Person Puzzler) and while the puzzles are not that hard, you do need to stop and think about them once in a while, which makes it just all more compelling (whats the fun when there is no challenge, right?).
Is it all good then? No, there are some lesser points to the game. First, it is really short and over before you know it. Second, some of the puzzles require this second perfect timing or pixel perfect jumping to complete and that can be frustrating sometimes (or perhaps i didn't solve them right?).

Первый раз я услышал об этой игре давным-давно,когда я учился в школе,у меня не было интернета и сформировавшегося мозга. Тогда мы обменивались дисками от игромании и прочих игровых журналов,и однажды мне попался диск с превью этой игры.Запала в душу... а потом я узнал,что Portal входит во вселенную Half-life.

Игра очень интересная,озвучка и субтитры на уровне.
Представьте себе,у меня есть знакомый, c ,мягко говоря,развитым интеллектом(университетов не кончал и тд), раньше он играл только в стрелялочки,да и то особо не вникая,зачем там стрелять и в кого - сам процесс движущихся картинок и звук пальбы - вот и всё,что ему было нужно.Игра Portal оказалась у него на компе совершенно случайно,он играл в нее всю ночь,а потом скачал и вторую часть!!!

По самой игре:

Поиграв в нее раз,многие из вас захотят чего-то еще...похожего(на это есть вторая часть - она длиннее по сюжету,смешнее, там есть мультиплеер и куча всего нового)

Ибо если проходить ее два-три раза,шутки-реплики быстро надоеют,потому-что они одни и те-же.
Какая-никакая система достижений присутствует.
Отсутствуют карточки коллекционные и сохранение в облаке.

Если захотите попробывать поиграть,то дождитесь распродажи

Parece raro, ¿verdad? Diferente y quizá no merezca la pena comprarlo a primera vista.
Pero puede que sea una de las mejores inversiones en el muno de los videojuegos que he hecho. Es magnífico, fantástico, precioso.
Tiene una mecánica nunca vista: puzles con "portales", cubos y más.
Muy original y entretenido. Quizá demasiado corto, pero cuando juegas a la secuela (Portal 2), ves que el primero sólo fue la introducción a una obra magnífica e inolvidable.
Un personaje (GLADoS) con un humor fantástico y una personalidad única, todo combinado con un estilo limpio y una batalla final que más que física se basa en algo innovador: la psicología.
Es una buenísima inversión, no tanto por éste juego, sino por la segunda parte (que supera unas 100 veces a ésta innovando, creando nuevos personajes, conociendo el pasado de "Aperture" y con una historia magnífica en la que descubrirás a GLADoS y, quizá, a tí misma).
Una primera parte magnífica para lo que, combinado con Portal 2, será inolvidable. Recomendadísimo.
Si te compras este, aprovecha y adquiere el segundo o te quedarás con dudas y ganas de más.
( Tranquilo, Portal 2 es mucho más largo ;) )
i really like it

[SPOILER ELERT CODE 1.0] dont read this if your thinking about getting the game just read the first and last paragraph.


You know, before i baught Portal, i allways heard people talking about portal 2. they said it was amazing. even the people from good game sayed it was amazing. and i saw both in the series were on sale. unfortunatly, my budget narrowed so i could no longer get portal 2. but it was a blessing in descise, because i could still afford number 1! and i loved it.

I managed to finish it in around 3 hours, even though it seemed like longer to me. the Game is Realy trippy. when your messing around with portals, you end up seeing your self on the sealing on the next room over through a window when you actualy on a platform above goop with the portal next to you in the wall! what IS this! its so awsome though. theres apsolutely tons of realy hard challenges that change depending on whats required in the room. theres even an 'advanced' level for each of the rooms for when youv finished the game wich i think is realy neat.
you start out as a female protagonist or test subject realy, in the strange testing faclilty of aperture proggramming and your tasked with navigating through a series of extencive rooms using the 'Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device', or portal gun. The portal gun can create two distinct portal ends, orange and blue. as you get farther and farther into the game the guide voice named GLaDOS helps you through the levels, and also briefs you on any legal liabilitys that Aperture may have and souch. your prommessed  a party with... Cake on completion of teh cource. but as you get closer and closer to the end, things get more and more shady untill you finally complete all of the tests. your being weeled along on a platform to 'your party' when you kind of notice its moving towards a massive pit of death. but if you act quickly then you can escape. GLaDOS doesnt know what your doing at first. you twist and wind your way through the service area's of the facility putting more and more peaces of the puzzle together. GLaDOS thinks your trying to find the exit and keeps telling you "im not mad. just turn back and we can all have cake, you not even going the right way. i was only joking about incinerating you" and so on. but you find the hidy hole of what seems to be the last protagonist. he seemed to be living there a wile. his hidy holes walls were covered with writting invlueding "the cake is a lie" over and over again. wich is when you realies shes lieing about my cake -_-. wich leads to the finall battle and the cliff hanger for the next in the series. 


its an amazing game, with charm and profile that will never leave the world. its a little outdated now, graphics mainly, but they remind me of halo 1 & 2 wich are still amazingly popular games. i would recomend grabbing this, before you get II. its realy worth it even when its not on sale. its a great game and frankly if you havent got it, then YOUR a lie. so get it. and enjoy it. try and play through all of the bonus advanced maps after you finsih it because the game isnt as long as things like Halo wich may or may not be anoying. but still its an amazing, trippy, magical game with the best steam achivemants ever. if you spawn a portal on the roof then the floor belowe it, then fall through the floor and out the ceeling then through the floor agin and again and again and it allmost made me through up watching the room fly past hundreds of times and watching hundreds of myselfs belowe me falling as well. but they did it so well that i just love it!
and i think you will too. if your more into downright deathmatches then dont get this game because it requires a level of Patience that isnt found often. but if your into your puzzle games and souch, this game will be a peace of... cake. im not lieing.
Simplemente genial. Un videojuego hecho para matar tu tiempo y hacerte reir un buen rato.

Portal

Sin lugar a dudas una obra maestra, muestra que los shooters no sólo tienen que ser de guerra, y cuenta una historia muy terrorífica. Con un antagonista mucho más que memorable, y con su humor único. 
El juego consiste en una serie de cámaras de pruebas, las cuales son puzles, de los cuales su dificultad ira aumentado hasta llegar al punto de que seguramente te traves en más de una cámara de pruebas. Una vez que lo terminas también podrás volver a jugar cámaras de pruebas pero cambiada para hacerlas más difíciles y presentarte un nuevo reto.
La historia del juego es simple, eres un sujeto de pruebas utilizado por una empresa, Aperture science. La historia toma su tono de terror de una forma indirecta, poniéndote en solitario y sin ver ninguna otra cara durante todo el juego. Más que  de terror de sustos, es un terror psicológico por el miedo que produce pensar que sos el único humano. 
Una compra obligada, aunque sea de oferta, debido a su entretenido y  único modo de juego.

----------NOTA FINAL: 9.5

It's good but short, I liked the experience being "Chell" and defeating GLaDos in Portal, I just recommend it.

9/10
